question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Answer:

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:

title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

### Question:
Determine whether the following formula is:
A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

(1) p1=::>(p1||p2||p3)
(2) (p1=::>~p1)=::>~p2

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
[[A];[A]]

### Question:
Convert the following two propositions into equivalent and maximally simplified formulas.
p1 = (p2&~(p3||(~(p1||p3))))
p2 = (~(p3&~(p1||p2)))=::>(p2||p1||~p3)

The answer should be formatted as [[Formula];[Formula]]. If there are multiple values in Formula, they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[~(p1&~(p2||p3))]];[[~(p1&p2)||~(p3||p1|p2)]]

title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

### Question:
Given that p1=::>(p1||p2) is a Truth Formula,
 ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula, 
determine the type of the following formulas:
(1) (p1=::>(p1||p2))&(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)
(2) (p1=::>(p1||p2))||(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
[[A];[A]]

### Question:
State VERIFIER the Notation Assignment:
Given logics violation, determine the literal in the original logical tree that has the NOT semantic in the translation phase.
The answer is in the format [[literal_name];[TRUE]].

### Answer:
[[
[p1],
[TRUE]
]]

### Question:
Assume a logical system consists of the following logical connectives and inference rules:

T: true
F: false 
♥: if p1 then q1
♦: p1 then q1 
♯: ¬p1 
⊕: (p1||p2) 
&: (p1=::>p2)
~a\→b: ~p1 P: P1 → (P2 → … → (Pn → P) → P, where n ≥ 2) and ~p1
q: q2 ∧ q3, and ~p1 ,~q1 
u: q1 ⇔ (q2 → q3), and ~p1 ,~q2, and ~q1 P: p1 ⇒ (p2 → p3), with p1, p2, and p3 being fresh literal variables ⇒: q1s → ¬ q2. and ~p1 q -> q2, for p1 is a fresh literal.
In the proof tree, if the proof is incorrect, then mark one or more literal names as a solution. Otherwise, if the proof is correct, then give a negative example that will be used to verify the solutions provided.

All the answers should be in the format [[literal_name];[TRUE]].

### Answer:
[[
p1
q1
[TRUE]
]]

question:
Using Basic Equivalences (10), what equivalent expression is obtained by removing all occurrences of > in (p > q) > r?
The answer is a logical expression formatted as [[ ]].! has the highest priority, and note that parentheses should only be used when logically needed to emphasise the order of operations, avoiding redundant or unnecessary brackets.
title: Equivalence Calculus
rule_content:
1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

### Question:
A = B !A \/ !B A > B ∧ A > !B
1. Which expression is equivalent to the above expression? Answer the sentence using single quotes.
No person will sleep after eating B.
USING [∨['B']]
2. Which expression is equivalent to the above expression? Answer the sentence using double quotes.
No person will sleep after eating B.
USING [∨{r'}]
The answer is a logical expression formatted as [[]].

### Answer:
[[ p -> !q ]]&[[ p -> q ]]

### Question:
Given the following equivalent expressions.
True
1. (A | B) ⇓ (B | A) B > A
2. (A & B) > (A & !B) & (B & !A) > ((A | B) & !A)
3. (A ⇑ !A) ⇑ ((A | B) ⇑ !B) & (B ⇑ !A) ⇑ ((A | B) ⇑ !B)
4. (A! | B!). A > B
5. !A > !B
Which expression is the most logical expression using only single characters?
6. A > B
What is the truth table for the logical expression?
7. p > q When q is true and p is true p will be false.
8. !p!q Which means q is false when p is false.
Provide your answers separated by unit in [[ [] ]].

### Answer:
[[p -> q ]]&[[ q -> !p ]]&[[ p -> !p ]]&[[ p -> q ]]

### Question:
Provide the truth table for the following given logical expression. The table consists of 8 rows labeled from 0 to 7.
True
p >> q
Provide your answers by listing a 3-digit logical expression (both beginning and ending 0) in ascending rows of the truth table. The answer should be separated by multiple space.
[[ ]]p > q

### Answer:
[0570]p & q

### Question:
Based on given logical expressions.
True
q > !p is equivalent to (q > p) & (q > !p) Same with p > !q.
Given q > !p is equivalent to ((!p | q) ⇑ (!p | !q))

2. What is the truth value of the top row cell's value? `X` will be used as `?`, Write the answer as [00]"""`.

### Answer:
[][1000]0p<<>>qp & q >> p

    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A ⇑ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A ⇓ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

### Question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou," 
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:
B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3=!p&q.(Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r).(Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3=q&r.(Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

According to Professor Wang's remarks, the final logical expression
E=(B1&C2&D3)|(B1&C3&D2)|(B2&C1&D3)|(B2&C3&D1)|(B3&C1&D2)|(B3&C2&D1)

After equivalent derivation according to the above rules:
(1) What does B1&C2&D3 simplify to?
(2) What does B1&C3&D2 simplify to?
(3) What does B2&C1&D3 simplify to?
(4) What does B2&C3&D1 simplify to?
(5) What does B3&C1&D2 simplify to?
(6) What does B3&C2&D1 simplify to?
(7) What does E finally simplify to?

Please provide the corresponding logical expressions. The answer format should be:
[[B1&C2&D3::=::…];[B1&C3&D2::=::…];[B2&C1&D3::=::…];[B2&C3&D1::=::…];[B3&C1&D2::=::…];[B3&C2&D1::=::…];[E::=::…]].

needle: In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).

If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.

Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.
prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Question:

[[pairedconjunctiveterms:p∧¬q∧r,¬p∧q∧¬r];[denoted:m2∨m5]]

### Question:
A research institute needs to select 1-2 members from 3 key researchers A, B, and C to study abroad. Due to work requirements, the selection must satisfy the following conditions:

1. If A goes, then C must go.
2. If B goes, then C cannot go.
3. If C does not go, then either A or B can go.

Let p: A goes
Let q: B goes
Let r: C goes

Based on the given conditions, the formula can be derived as:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q))

The true assignments of this formula are the feasible selection schemes. Through derivation, we get:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q)) ↔ (¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r), which can be denoted as m1 ∨ m2 ∨ m5. 
Based on the three true assignments represented, what are the feasible selection schemes? 

Only give the letters of the people selected to go, separated by commas within a scheme, and different schemes separated by []; format: [[];[];..].

### Answer:
response:
[[asp,bcr],[qual],[ess]]

### Question:
Based on the question about 1-2 members to be selected, you can express the selected feasibility if the answer is multiple sentences, or you can express the selected feasibility if the answer is detailed combinations of operators, members, and negations (such as: A, not B, C; use symbols & or except for the specified members as the logical operator].
The operator & stands for "selected more than one time going" and the operator except stands for "selected but did not specify". 
Negation symbol and operator are separately used for the selection and exclusions.
The selected schemes can be quoted as a logical expression, but it is recommended to fol diet exactly. The answer should be in the format [[p1̸,p2̸,...p|,q1̸,q2̸,...{q]ives followigs:egtcs]];[denoted:...,...]; or [p1̸,p2̸,...p|,q1̸,q2̸,...{q]ives followigs:egtcs];[denoted:...]].

### Answer:
[(¬p & ¬q & r) ∨ (¬p & q & ¬r) ∨ (p & ¬q & r)] 
denoted: m1 &; m2 &; m5 |

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.
title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.

    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.

    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:

            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

title: Circuit Diagram
rule_content:
In a simple circuit diagram, logical operators "negation", "conjunction", and "disjunction" function similarly.
When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

Please provide a simple circuit diagram for a AND gate, 
formatted as [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].
needle: When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O".
title: Circuit Diagram
rule_content:
In a simple circuit diagram, logical operators "negation", "conjunction", and "disjunction" function similarly.
When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

### Logic Rule:

In a simple circuit diagram, logical operators "negation", "conjunction", and "disjunction" function similarly.
When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

question:
In first-order logic, symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:
(1) Only 2 is a prime number, 4 is a composite number.
(2) If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x is a prime number. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate G(x, y): x > y. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].
needle: Implication: Use ⇒

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.
Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:

(1) Only cats like fish, dogs like bones.
(2) If apples are bigger than oranges, then oranges are bigger than cherries.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x likes fish, and a unary predicate G(y): y likes bones.
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate H(x, y): x > y.
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].

### Answer:
[[F(cat)⇒G(dog)];[H(apple,orange)⇒H(orange,cherry)]]

### Question:
Let the individual domain D be the set of all integers.
For the following statements, indicate whether the corresponding finite proposition is valid, to be symbolised as [[]], incorrect, to be symbolised as [[]], or ambiguous to be symbolised as [[]].
(1) ExAx(F(x)>>F(x));
(2) ExFX(F(x)>>G(x));
(3) ExG(x) & Aud(x);
(4) AxG(x) & AyG(y);
(5) Ax(G(x)VH(x,y)) & Ay(G(y)VH(y,x));
(6) AxF(x) & AyF(y) & (G(x)VH(y,x)) & (H(x,y)VG(y)) & (G(y)VF(x)) & (H(y, x)VF(x)) & (H(x,y)VF(y))

Propositions (1) and (4) are mistakenly written as [[]] by guessing.
Propositions (2) and (5) are ambiguous.
Propositions (3) and (6) are also mistakenly written as [[]] by guessing.

More formally,
(1) ExAx(F(x)>>F(x)) = invalid because the variable names are different. The true statement is ExG(F(x)>>F(x)).
(2) ExF(x)>>G(x) & ExG(y)>>H(y, x) indicates "There exists a sequence F(x), G(x), H(x, y) such that F(x)>>G(x) and G(x)>>H(x, y) where H(x,y)”. This is indeed true for the domain {0,1} because of availability of only two integer numbers, which are 0 and 1. But this is not valid in the case of the general real number domain of the [-1,2] interval.
(3) ExG(x) & Aud(x) = ambiguous, because the quantifiers are for individual variables whereas G(x) asks for quantifiers over the domain.
(4) associative identity when categorical predicates are used.
(5) ExAx(F(x)>>G(x)) & ExAy(G(y)>>H(y, x)) = ambiguous. This is valid only when x and y are objects identifiers such as object "1", object "2" and so on.
(6) equivalences when 2-ary predicates are used.

title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

needle: Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
- Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
- Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
- Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
- Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.
title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

Direct Propositions:

- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

question:
Person A: Hey, speaking is really an art, and not being able to speak well can easily offend people.
Person B: Oh? How so?
Person A: My grandfather is a case in point. He speaks very straightforwardly and often does good deeds with bad intentions. I remember one time he invited some friends over for dinner.
Person B: That's nice, everyone can get together.
Person A: The appointment was for six in the evening, and by half past five, three people had arrived, but one important guest hadn't shown up yet.
Person B: Then wait a bit longer, if they don't come, start eating without them.
Person A: My grandfather is a punctual person. When it was half past six and that guest still hadn't arrived, he got anxious and said to himself, "The ones who should come are not those who come." As a result, one of the guests got upset, thinking they were the one who shouldn't have come, and left.
Person B: That's really a misunderstanding.
Person A: With two guests left, my grandfather was still waiting, and then he said, "The ones who have left were the ones who should have stayed." Another guest felt there was no sincerity and also left.
Person B: How could he say that, another one left.

question:
What method should be used to infer a proposition with "formally correct reasoning" as the subject from "All correct reasoning is formally correct reasoning"?

needle: 1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
title: Derivative Reasoning of Propositional Logic
rule_content:
Method A
- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All S is not non-P.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All S is non-P.
    3. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some S is not non-P.
    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.

Jeanette Bloomfields manual, p19 ### Question: Please fill in the formula below ∃A⇒M⇒S, ∀S⇒M⇒P, A⇒P⇒M ⇒B. ### Answer: [[III];[Y]] ### Question: Please fill in the logic symbol for the premises of: 1) ∀N⇒P ⇒ ∃M⇒N? ### Answer: [[A];[];[]] ### Question: Please fill in the logic symbol for the premises of: 1) ∀N⇒P ⇒ ∃M⇒N. ### Answer: [[A];[];[P]] ### Question: Please fill in the logic symbol for the premises of: 2) ∀S⇒M ⇒ ∃R⇒S. ### Answer: [[A];[P];[]] ### Question: Prove the following syllogism: AII / | D C | | E F | | P S O Parts 1-6 are the premises of the argument. Prove or disprove the conclusion, using rules and reasoning patterns as specified. ### Answer: Well this is an analogous syntagmatic syllogism, so it could not violate X Rule: this entails nullification, which is an impossible precondition for a landscape premise. Siemion writes (PW 708): Under the Matrix Rule of analogous Syllogism, the first Figure is that in every instance of the basic proposition’s first assumption, as for example those in ML and LR, the empty premise, has the same antecedent and the same consequate as the first assumption, and is congruent according to the same Proposition Rule. It follows that the first assumptions of parentheses MI and LM, which in this case is ML that we are examining, have their assumptive momentum choked off before the assumptions in parentheses. This is true, and there are some premises that are small and the first assumptions are null, as you can see from P and Q. The conclusion relies on the primitive land. But P and Q are empirical, they do not follow the syllogism, so the existential is only conclusive. So O and R have to be false. ### Question: Given the premises: ∀S⇒M⇒O, ∀N⇒P ⇒∀R⇒S. Determine which figure and mood of syllogism the argument corresponds to, using the format [[X/Y/Z];[AAI]]. Here, X refers to concerned figure, Y to the valid moods, and Z to the format (See below for definitions). ### Answer: {%raw %}[[III;[AAI]]]
Figure III
AAI stands for: BACK DOOR II IS IN PLACE. Cf. Jeanette Bloomfields manual, p19 ### Question: On the given sentence, is it necessary that the moon is physically present in the night sky? Should the question read: "For all of the nights that I have seen the moon, it has been physically present in the night sky." The more general Mooney/Bovier question is a variation of Van Inwagen's, and takes note of Hume's view that knowledge is a relation to an agent. The question that Van Inwagen asks is "Is it implicit with my knowledge of the world that the following must be the truth": that syllable "must." To a Humean, knowledge is a particular way of relating to an object. Intelligence is distinctions. So, instrumentally, knowing things says nothing about the way that an object is physically known. A neutral answer here must be "no." In order to modify or invert knowledge questions, we need to understand what senses of knowing we'd like to speak of. The question of how the world is to be known is a genuinely difficult one. If knowledge is Lycan/Mooney's relation to a particular object about which there is a perspectival necessity, then the answer here is no. If knowledge is relation to perspectival impossibilities then the answer is yes. Still, even if the moon is a bare possibility such that, notoriously, there is no moon, then it would seem that the answer to the question must remain the same. ### Question: P: The actualist view of coherence retains a fundamental contrast between necessity and contingency, however it maintains that there is no intrinsic “planarity” to necessity: contingency and necessity may both be “vertical” (i.e. posited in disparate points in the conceptual strictures thus posited), or “horizontal” (i.e. posited under the same conditions). C: Such a notion of a “vertical” world should properly be distinguished from ontological “depth” considerations (cf. the considerations of Bernard Stiegler). and combine these into: 1:What distinguishes vertical worlds from horizontal ones? 1:Vertical worlds retain both real difference ((Dharmadhatuo: indivisibility) or sub-(puresubjunctivity) or indivisibility of the real difference, or localization to a place/2nd: horizontal worlds lack the real difference subjunctivity. 2:On the vertical, objects are not based on the subsumption of something. Objects only self-describe to the compatibility of each sub-function. In this view, there are different layers of function for things (similar to layers of functionalism, foundationalism, etc, in the realm of ontology). 1) A car is based upon the functions of a thing that has as a goal the drive (which indicates the motor driving a wheel). 2) A driver is based upon a person that needs to drive something. The driver may be a machine or flesh and blood, as long as the vehicle drives itself (and is useful for the being). 3) The driver may drive a car for the goal of extracting oil which may be burned to power a boat that one could row. 4) Each of layers is a function that is compatible with the Real, which is not necessarily (the chosen object as a being) The horizontal world, one could say is a cartesian product, one could say it based upon brute exposure, or one could say that the sine qua non is exposing the objects features by deconstructing it into basic concepts. Apply abstraction to something and convert it into properties, and then informational content. It is not a matter of real difference, perspectival necessity, and differences. Nor is layering, one-dimensional entities which have extra dimensions of being scaled via the cartesian product. Why In the vertical world, the basic “type” determines the fundamental type, which is a wider set of elementsunderstanding differences. In contrast, for puresubjunctivity, in the horizontal world, the world is built as a basehe>>q>rd=the established, through which to map/trace our realities. ### Question: P: In the traditional notion of a ‘bad reason,’ the individual is seen as motivated by synonymous /

needle: Symbols: Use # for necessity, $ for possibility, letters like p, q, r... for propositions, ! for negation, + for conjunction, - for disjunction, = for equivalence, and > for implication.
title: Truth-Value Modal Propositions
rule_content:
Symbols: Use # for necessity, $ for possibility, letters like p, q, r... for propositions, ! for negation, + for conjunction, - for disjunction, = for equivalence, and > for implication.

1. Four Modal Proposition Relationships:
(1) * Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and $¬p; #¬p and $p
- Property: They cannot both be true or both be false.

(2) x Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and #¬p
- Property: They cannot both be true, but they can both be false.

(3) @ Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: $p and $¬p
- Property: They cannot both be false, but they can both be true.

(4) % Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and $p; #¬p and $¬p
- Property: They can both be true or both be false.

2. Modal Logic Inference Formulas:
(1) #p ←→ !$!p
(2) $p ←→ !#!p
(3) #!p ←→ !$p
(4) $!p ←→ !#p
(5) #p → !#!p
(6) #!p → !#p
(7) !$p → $!p
(8) !$!p → $p
(9) #p → $p
(10) #!p → $!p
(11) !$p → !#p
(12) !$!p → !#!p
(13) #p → p
(14) #!p → !p
(15) p → $p
(16) !p → $!p

### Question:
Which of the following inferences from a $$\neg$$p → q to $$\neg$$p is a fallacy?

A. The negative statement of the conditional p → q interpreted as "If p is false, then q is true". And the inverse of p → q is p ↔ q which is "If p is true, then q is false". An inverted hypothesis is then q ↔ \neg p.
B.The negative statement of the conditional p → q interpreted as "If p is true, then q is false", and the inverse of p → q is p ↔ q. Thus, q ↔ \neg p

needle: The symbols are defined as follows: ¶ represents obligation modality, § represents permission modality, and ‽ represents prohibition modality.
title: Canonical Propositions
rule_content:
1. The symbols are defined as follows: ¶ represents obligation modality, § represents permission modality, and ‽ represents prohibition modality.
2. The four types of normative propositions relationships are:

(1) * relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and §¬p; ‽p and §p
- Nature: Both cannot be true and cannot be false.

(2) x relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and ‽p
- Nature: Both cannot be true, but can both be false.

(3) @ relationship:
- Propositional pairs: §p and §¬p
- Nature: Both cannot be false, but can both be true.

(4) % relationship:
- **Propositional pairs**: ¶p and §p; ‽p and §¬p
- **Nature**: Both can be true, and both can be false.

3. Normative reasoning formulas
(1) ¶p←→¬§¬p
(2) ‽p←→¬§p
(3) §p←→¬‽p
(4) §¬p←→¬¶p
(5) ¶p→¬‽p
(6) ‽p→¬¶p
(7) ¬§p→§¬p
(8) ¬§¬p→§p
(9) ¶p→§p
(10) ‽p→§¬p
(11) ¬§p→¬¶p
(12) ¬§¬p→¬‽p

### Instructions:

UCSEM models the relationship between the meaning of expressions of security, e.g., value, belief, threat, and the structure of operations in computer systems, e.g., control, access, and communication.

UCSEM operations include:

A control operation is an operation that establishes or maintains a relationship between the access rights of users via roles in the system and certain system resources in the security domain. For example, it includes:

* Creating a requirement
* Modifying an ALLOW/GENERATE control on a specified resource

Access operations are operations that satisfy the requirements of system resources in the security domain. The roles of the users that satisfy the requirements of the resources are expressed in the system. For example, it includes:

* Creating a new REQUIREMENT
* Allowing a resource

Communication operations are operations that establish, transmit, or maintain a communication flow between programs or users. For example, it includes:

* Modifying the communication RELATIONSHIP of the specified object or system resource
* Creating a new communication RELATIONSHIP

## Complex Sentence Logic Rules and Calculator

Another set of logic formulas whose application in solving complex logic problems coincides with a rule of inference that is commonly used because it predominantly increases the validity of the argument, as well as make the meaning clearer and more accurate. These rules are Synthetic Absurdity, Conditional on Overlapping Conttect, Reversible Trichotomy, and Idempotent.

The Synthetic Absurdity suggests that making a statement dependent on a contradiction cannot be real. This, in turn, means that every statement which is logically dependent on a given statement can be excluded. However, that does not mean that it will certainly assume the value of false, it only raises the so-called Synthetic Absurdity Assumption, that if a proposition, i.e., a statement that is logically dependent on a true statement remained false, then that true statement would be contradicted. Another way to describe this, based on Aristotle's dialectical method, is to say that every contradictory proposition is impossible to be true.

Using an example, suppose an evidence 'John Don.' contradicts a hypothesis 'Jane Don.'. If we were to apply this rule in a logical statement believed to be true regarding this two propositions, which means that we accept that anything that is logically dependent on an evidence p is only true when it is not true or can be found in a true state, then every statement which is believes to be true while still accepting a statement false became possible. For example, we could state that there are some people named John Don. or John Don. is female.

The Conditional on Overlapping Assumption, as its name indicates, is based on information that fails in expression when certain parts overlap. For example, let's say that once a teacher assigns a student to paint a blue object, the student can paint any object that is blue or at least any artistic work that features some shade of blue or it could paint an existing object like one that is displayed in a museum. Furthermore, if the bookmark used by Jane has a light blue color, that is this list of assumptions.

Trichotomy is based on falsehood logic. The Reversible Trichotomy states that any conditional statement that is claimed to be true is true under one condition of the following; it is either true, or true but under a different set of circumstances, otherwise it would be false.

There is an increasing number of psychological studies that characterize how these rules can affect our life. It states that we tend to make the same mistakes in endorsing and rejecting evidence, consequently ending up with a concludtioal set of conclusions based on a false premise.

The Idempotent rule focuses on the proposition's basic meaning, which includes the elements that state, can, and must, among others. If a statement uses the modal logic, like sumo cases and deontological, then Idempotent is useful. The term 'was' must be replaced with the 'is,' and the term 'must' must be replaced with 'is. This rule has less influence on discourses.

## Conclusion

The above mentioned logical rules and calculators can be used in various types of systems by observing the properties that have been mentioned in the previous paragraphs. First, they act as a decision-making tool to move on to different states, like reaching a present state from a past state. Second, they are useful in some kinds of research as they explore the rules of reasoning that exist in some algorithm or methods, like the XOR method or brute force methods.

needle: - Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

question:
According to the Axiom of Reflexivity, what does it mean if Alice firmly believes a certain proposition to be true?

A. Alice may have doubts about this proposition.
B. Alice is convinced that she herself is convinced of this proposition.
C. Alice and other people are all aware of this proposition.

Please provide the answers in the format [[A/B/C]].
needle: - Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

### Question:
If every member of a group `G` firmly believes in proposition `p`, is `p` considered a common belief within that group?

A. Yes

B. No

Please provide your answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

C. `H_ip` will cause `j` to strengthen their belief in `p` .

Please provide your answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

C. `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥ C.B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`

Please provide your answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

A. Alice may have doubts about this proposition.
B. Alice is convinced that she herself is convinced of this proposition.
C. Alice and other people are all aware of this proposition.
